code: import img2 from'./view.jpeg';import img1 from'./kite.jpeg';import img3 from'./food.jpeg';import img4 from'./temple.jpeg';import img5 from'./fight.jpeg';import img6 from'./food2.jpeg';export var content=[{id:1,img:img1,heading:"Makar Sankranti",para:"Makara Sankranti or Maghi or simply Sankranthi, is a festival day in the Hindu calendar, dedicated to the deity Surya (sun). It is observed each year in the lunar month of Magha which corresponds with the month of January as per the Gregorian calendar and is a day the people of India and Nepal celebrate their harvest."},{id:2,img:img2,heading:"Date",para:"Makara Sankranti is set by the solar cycle of the Hindu lunisolar calendar, and is observed on a day which usually falls on 14 January of the Gregorian calendar, but sometimes on 15 January.It signifies the arrival of longer days."},{id:3,img:img3,heading:"Significance",para:"Every year Makar Sankranti is celebrated in the month of January to mark the winter solstice. It is also one of the largely celebrated Hindu festivals of India and Nepal which is celebrated differently in various cultures but the common practice on the day of Makar Sankranti is flying colourful kites."},{id:4,img:img4,heading:"Nomenclature and regional names",para:"Makara or Makar Sankranti is celebrated in many parts of the Indian subcontinent with some regional variations. It is known by different names and celebrated with different customs in different Indian states and South Asian countries"},{id:5,img:img5,heading:"Regional variations",para:"It is celebrated differently across the Indian subcontinent. Many people take a dip in places like Ganga Sagar Prayag and pray to the Sun God (Surya). It is celebrated with pomp in southern parts of India as Sankranti in Karnataka (Pongal in Tamil Nadu), and in Punjab as Maghi."},{id:6,img:img6,heading:"Outside India",para:"On this day, the Tamil farmers & the Tamil People honour the Sun God Suriya Narayanan. This happens when the sun enters the zodiac sign of Capricorn (Makara). The Thai Pongal festival is celebrated in mid-January, or the Tamil month of Thai, to coincide with the rice harvest"}];

sourcesContent:
import img2 from './view.jpeg'
import img1 from './kite.jpeg'
import img3 from './food.jpeg'
import img4 from './temple.jpeg'
import img5 from './fight.jpeg'
import img6 from './food2.jpeg'

export let content = [
    {
        id : 1,
        img : img1,
        heading : "Makar Sankranti",
        para : "Makara Sankranti or Maghi or simply Sankranthi, is a festival day in the Hindu calendar, dedicated to the deity Surya (sun). It is observed each year in the lunar month of Magha which corresponds with the month of January as per the Gregorian calendar and is a day the people of India and Nepal celebrate their harvest.",
    },

    {
        id : 2,
        img : img2,
        heading : "Date",
        para : "Makara Sankranti is set by the solar cycle of the Hindu lunisolar calendar, and is observed on a day which usually falls on 14 January of the Gregorian calendar, but sometimes on 15 January.It signifies the arrival of longer days.",
    },

    {
        id : 3,
        img : img3,
        heading : "Significance",
        para : "Every year Makar Sankranti is celebrated in the month of January to mark the winter solstice. It is also one of the largely celebrated Hindu festivals of India and Nepal which is celebrated differently in various cultures but the common practice on the day of Makar Sankranti is flying colourful kites.",
    },

    {
        id : 4,
        img : img4,
        heading : "Nomenclature and regional names",
        para : "Makara or Makar Sankranti is celebrated in many parts of the Indian subcontinent with some regional variations. It is known by different names and celebrated with different customs in different Indian states and South Asian countries",
    },

    {
        id : 5,
        img : img5,
        heading : "Regional variations",
        para : "It is celebrated differently across the Indian subcontinent. Many people take a dip in places like Ganga Sagar Prayag and pray to the Sun God (Surya). It is celebrated with pomp in southern parts of India as Sankranti in Karnataka (Pongal in Tamil Nadu), and in Punjab as Maghi.",
    },

    {
        id : 6,
        img : img6,
        heading : "Outside India",
        para : "On this day, the Tamil farmers & the Tamil People honour the Sun God Suriya Narayanan. This happens when the sun enters the zodiac sign of Capricorn (Makara). The Thai Pongal festival is celebrated in mid-January, or the Tamil month of Thai, to coincide with the rice harvest",
    },
]
